title: Priti Patel told ‘I don’t know why you’re laughing’ over Brexit fears
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

Andrew Marr told off Home Secretary Priti Patel like a disappointed teacher when she appeared on his show today.

The BBC presenter was asking her about the potentially damaging effects of a hard Brexit on British business.

He then stopped midway to say: ‘I don’t see why you’re laughing.’

Some claimed Ms Patel was ‘smirking’ as he listed the business organisations with concerns about Brexit policy.

But others, such as Tory MP Nadhim Zahawi, defended her saying she was ‘neither smiling or laughing’.

The exchange happened on the Andrew Marr show, with Ms Patel being interviewed via a video link to the studio rather than in person.

He told her: ‘I can’t see why you’re laughing’ (Picture: BBC)

Mr Marr said to her: ‘Let’s hear from those business directly, because there’s a whole bunch of them. I’ll read them out: The Society for Motor Manufacturers and Traders, the people who make and sell cars; the Chemical Industries Association; the Food and Drink Federation; the Association for British Pharmaceutical Industry; and the Aerospace trade industry body. A lot of people who are actually at the forefront of trying to make this country earn its place in the world sent a letter to the government which I will now read out part of to you.

‘They said that this proposal is a serious risk to manufacturing competitiveness, and will result in huge new costs and disruption to UK firms.

‘I can’t see why you’re laughing.’

‘It’s got the potential to risk consumer and food safety and confidence, access to overseas markets for UK exporters, and vital future investment in innovation in this country.’

Ms Patel did not respond to the laughing claim, but told him: ‘This is why the government has been working assiduously – with business as well I should say – across a range of sectors when it comes to planning for our exit from the European Union.’

.Accept she is neither smiling or laughing. I guess some people are so incensed at the thought of a Gov that is upholding the Democratic will of the people,they are willing to use any means necessary to demonise its Ministers. Maybe @AndrewMarr9 can apologise to @patel4witham now — Nadhim Zahawi (@nadhimzahawi) October 13, 2019

Nadhim Zahawi responded online saying: ‘I guess some people are so incensed at the thought of a Gov that is upholding the democratic will of the people,they are willing to use any means necessary to demonise its ministers.

‘Maybe Andrew Marr can apologise to Priti Patel now.’

Those online were split over whether she deserved the rebuke or not.

Victoria Drummond wrote: ‘No she wasn’t laughing. But she was smirking. Which shows how arrogant and insulting her attitude is to thought of industries leaving or going bust and people becoming unemployed.’

Another user wrote: ‘It really is the expression of a person who is trying to hold in a laugh. Which is worse than an outright laugh in this case.’

However, Patrick O’Flynn wrote that she was ‘barely smiling. Only in a Mona Lisa type of way – is she or isn’t she? – perhaps. Marr’s outburst was unfair, being totally wrong.’
